parts.text:
The fabric of his tweed jacket, a beloved Harris tweed his wife had given him for his fiftieth, felt like a cage of sandpaper against his skin. Arthur Albright sat with his hands folded on the cold metal table, the gesture a desperate attempt to stop their trembling. He stared at the blank, cream-coloured wall of the interview room, a colour chosen, he presumed, for its supposed calming effect. It wasn't working. All he could see, projected onto that placid surface, was a face of granite and moss, split by a grin that was all tombstone teeth. And the hands. Gods, the hands. Fingers as thick as sausages, yet nimble, shockingly nimble, digging into his sides, his armpits, the tender flesh just above his hipbones.

He shuddered, a full-body tremor that rattled the cheap chair. The laughter had been the worst part. It wasn't a sound of mirth. It was a grinding, geological sound, like boulders being dragged over a gravel bed. A sound of pure, malicious glee that had echoed in the empty school hallway, a place that was supposed to be his sanctuary.

"Just once more, Mr. Albright," said the officer, a woman with a kind but weary face. "From the top."

From the top. As if it were a story he was recounting, a curious anecdote. Not a violation that had stripped the dignity from his bones. He was a history teacher. He dealt in facts, in timelines, in the orderly progression of human folly. There was no category for this. No precedent in his well-ordered life for being ambushed after parent-teacher conferences, pinned against a locker by a creature of impossible strength, and… and tickled into breathless, humiliating submission.

He couldn't get the smell out of his nostrils. Wet earth. Old cellars. The kind of primordial dampness that clings to forgotten things. And beneath it, something sharper, an acidic tang like bile or a centuries-old resentment. She had spoken, her voice a low rumble that vibrated through his ribcage. "This is for poisoning their minds," the creature—the woman? It was shaped like a woman, a brutally large one—had rasped, her breath a hot, foul wind against his cheek. "Lessons need to be taught. And you, teacher, are first on the syllabus."

Then the blogging. The ultimate degradation. A student, a nervous girl named Chloe with a piercing in her eyebrow, had shown it to him on her phone, her eyes wide with a mixture of horror and morbid fascination. A blog, crudely designed with a background of what looked like grinning gargoyles. It was called "The Righteous Rebuke." And there it was. A post, uploaded less than an hour after the attack.

*Tonight’s lesson was in Humility. Mr. Arthur Albright, of the esteemed Northgate Comprehensive, learned that spreading filth about deviant lifestyles has consequences. He squealed like a piglet, his little tweed jacket all rumpled. He thought he was so clever with his "inclusive history" posters. He's not so clever now, is he? He’s just another weakling who can’t take a JOKE. This is only the beginning. The faculty lounge is a den of vipers, and I have come to charm them.*

The post was signed: Lorhainne.

The name was a slap. So mundane. So normal. It didn't fit the granite-faced, moss-flecked horror from the hallway.

Sergeant Ana Karrington scrolled through the blog, her finger cool and precise on the mouse wheel. The name Lorhainne was a splinter in her mind. It was a cheap frill on a monstrous thing. The Righteous Rebuke. The sheer pomposity was galling. She took a sip of her coffee, black and bitter, the way her father used to drink it on cold Belgrade mornings before his shift. The small, sterile office of Interpol's Special Anomalies Division felt a million miles from those mornings. SAD, the division was called. The acronym was a point of grim humour among its handful of operatives. They dealt with the truly strange, the crimes that regular police forces kicked upstairs with a nervous shudder. The crimes that didn't fit into neat boxes.

And Lorhainne, this tickling troll, was decidedly out of the box.

This was the fourth one. Four teachers in three months. All in London. All ambushed. All tickled. All publicly humiliated on this odious blog. The first victim, a PE teacher, had been too embarrassed to even file a proper report, talking vaguely of a "prank by some rugby lads." The second, a young art teacher, had quit her job and moved back in with her parents in Devon. The third, a chemistry teacher, had tried to fight back and ended up with a dislocated shoulder and two cracked ribs. The "tickling" was a misnomer. It was assault, pure and simple. An assault cloaked in a bizarre, almost childish methodology that made the authorities reluctant to take it seriously.

But Ana Karrington took it very seriously.

She leaned closer to the screen, her dark eyes scanning the text of the latest post. Lorhainne’s prose was a toxic soup of self-righteousness and poorly-spelled bigotry. The homophobia was the engine, the sputtering, crude motor that drove the whole ugly vehicle. Each victim had been targeted for a specific reason. The PE teacher had proposed a gender-neutral sports uniform. The art teacher had curated a student exhibition celebrating queer artists. The chemistry teacher was the faculty advisor for the school’s LGBTQ+ Alliance. And Mr. Albright, poor Mr. Albright, had simply put up a poster of Alan Turing and Harvey Milk.

The common thread wasn't just the schools or the tickling. It was a focused, obsessive hatred. A hatred that felt deeply, pathologically personal. This wasn't a prank. It was a crusade.

Her desk phone buzzed, a jarring sound in the quiet room. It was her superior, Superintendent Davies.
"Karrington. My office." The line went dead.

Ana stood, smoothing the front of her simple, dark grey trousers. She walked past the small, framed photograph on her desk. It was her only personal item: a stark, black-and-white shot of the Pančevo Bridge, its steel lattice stark against a winter sky. A reminder of home. A reminder of what happens when hatred is allowed to fester, when neighbours turn on neighbours. She had been a child during the worst of it, but the memories were etched into her like names on a monument. She had seen what happens when dehumanizing rhetoric goes unchallenged. It starts with words, then it becomes something else. It might not always be bombs and checkpoints. Sometimes, it was a creature with granite hands and a blog, who believed she had the right to "correct" people.

Davies’s office was larger than hers, with a window overlooking a perpetually grey London courtyard. He was a man built of solid, English rectangles, from his jaw to his shoulders to the way he held his teacup. He gestated his disapproval in silence, letting it fill the room.
"Sergeant," he began, not looking at her, instead staring at a file on his desk. "This... tickler. It's making the rounds. The Daily Mail has a headline. 'Giggling Menace Plagues Our Schools.' They're treating it like a farce."

"It isn't a farce, sir," Ana said, her voice even. "It's targeted intimidation. It's a hate crime. The methodology is unorthodox, but the intent is clear."

"The intent," Davies sighed, finally looking up. His eyes were tired. "The intent is to make a fool of people. It’s some crackpot with a vendetta and a stupid blog. The Met can handle it. Why is SAD involved? We have... bigger fish." He gestured vaguely, as if to encompass the spectral horrors and interdimensional smugglers that usually occupied their time.

"Because the victim descriptions are consistent," Ana pressed, stepping forward. "Extremely tall. Unusually strong. A face described as 'craggy,' 'like stone.' A 'musky, earthy' smell. This is not 'some crackpot.' This is, by our own definition, an anomaly. And she is escalating."

Davies steepled his fingers. He was a good man, a logical man, but he was a man who liked evidence to be quantifiable, to fit on a spreadsheet. Trolls who blogged about tickling teachers did not fit. "What have you got, Karrington? Anything concrete? Anything besides the ramblings of humiliated teachers and a website that looks like it was designed in 1998?"

"I have a linguistic profile," Ana said, her mind already back in her office, on her screen. "The syntax, the repeated phrases... 'poisoning their minds,' 'lessons need to be taught.' It's highly specific. And the targets. They weren't chosen at random. I’ve been cross-referencing their professional schedules. All four attended the 'Future Forward in Education' conference at the ExCeL Centre two weeks before the first attack."

That got his attention. A sliver of it, at least. "A conference. A lead. Good. See where it goes. But Ana," he leaned forward, his voice dropping, "tread carefully. We don't have the political capital to go on a public witch-hunt for a... tickle monster. Keep it quiet. Keep it contained. Find a human explanation."

Ana nodded, though a knot of frustration tightened in her stomach. A human explanation. Davies still wanted this to be a person in a mask, a bodybuilder with a skin condition. He couldn't, or wouldn't, make the same leap she had. She had spent her youth in a city where folklore and reality bled into one another, where grandmothers would warn you about the things that lived in the shadows of the old fortress. She was more open to the impossible. This Lorhainne felt old. Ancient, even. An ancient hatred poured into a new, digital bottle.

Back in her office, the coffee now cold, Ana pulled up the attendance list for the conference. Over two thousand names. A digital haystack. She sipped the cold, acidic coffee anyway, the bitterness a familiar anchor. She wouldn't find Lorhainne on the list of attendees. Lorhainne wouldn't want to be in a room with these people. She would have been outside. Protesting. Watching.

Ana switched tactics. She began to scour social media, local forums, anything tagged with the conference's name and location, but she filtered for negative sentiment. She waded through a sea of complaints about the price of sandwiches, the lack of parking, the boring keynote speaker. It was a slow, painstaking process, the digital equivalent of combing a beach for a single, distinctive pebble. Hours bled into one another. The office lights hummed. The city outside grew dark.

Then she found it.

It wasn't a blog post. It wasn't a public tweet. It was a comment, buried deep in the discussion section of a fringe political news site, on an article decrying the conference as "a brainwashing session for the nation's youth." The comment was long, a rambling, semi-coherent tirade. But the language… it was unmistakable.

*They gather like maggots on a carcass, these "educators," to plot how they can further poison our children's minds. They talk of inclusion and diversity, but they mean perversion and decay. Someone needs to teach THEM a lesson. Someone needs to remind them that there are older, truer things in this world. They think their lecture halls are safe. They are not. A righteous rebuke is coming. They will laugh, but it will be the laughter of fear.*

The username was not Lorhainne. It was "StoneHeart1968."

It was a thread. A loose, frayed thread, but it was the first one she had been able to pull. Ana's heart began to beat a little faster. She ran the new username through her deep search programs. Dozens of hits, spanning years. Forum posts on anti-immigration sites. Comments on conspiracy theory videos. An old, deleted LiveJournal account. A profile on a website for enthusiasts of ancient British geology and folklore.

The profile picture on the folklore site was a blurry image of a dolmen, a Neolithic tomb, stark against a grey sky. The biography was brief. "A believer in old ways and hard truths. The land remembers what the people forget. London is a cancer on a green and pleasant land."

And in a photo album on the LiveJournal, dated ten years prior, a picture. It was a group photo from what looked like a protest outside a city council building. The protest signs were about preserving some old ruin. In the back of the group, half-obscured by a large banner, was a woman. She was unnaturally tall, towering over the others. Her face was out of focus, but the shape of it was there. Broad, craggy, with a jawline like a cliff edge. She wasn't smiling. She was sneering.

Ana zoomed in, the image pixelating into a meaningless mosaic of squares. But she had seen enough. The thread was tightening. StoneHeart1968. The name felt closer to the truth than the frilly, deceptive 'Lorhainne.' A heart of stone. The creature from Arthur Albright's nightmares was beginning to resolve, moving from the realm of myth into the stark, searchable reality of data. And Ana Karrington, the girl from Belgrade, felt the old, familiar thrill of the hunt. This was the moment the monster ceased to be a ghost and became a target.

The protest. She focused on the protest. The banner was partially legible, something about "heritage" and "roots." Using the EXIF data from the image file—a long shot, but sometimes people were careless—she confirmed the date: June 12th, 2012. Ten years ago. She ran a search through news archives for protests in London on that date related to heritage or historical buildings. It took less than five minutes. The event was a minor news item, a footnote in the city’s relentless march of development. A small but vocal group had protested the demolition of the old Blackfriars Pumphouse, a derelict Victorian structure slated to be replaced by a block of luxury flats.

The article was brief, accompanied by a clearer picture of the protest group. And there she was again. StoneHeart1968. This time she was in sharper focus, standing at the edge of the crowd as if she were their grim, silent shepherd. She wore a heavy, shapeless coat despite the June date. Her face was a study in grim permanence, a face you might find carved into a windswept tor, all heavy brow and a wide, unsmiling mouth. The article quoted the group's spokesperson, a flustered local historian, who spoke of ley lines and the building's unique brickwork, which incorporated stones from the original medieval priory. But the last paragraph mentioned an "unidentified woman" who had shouted at the construction crew, her voice described by one witness as "like rocks grinding together." The woman had been escorted away by police but not arrested.

A righteous rebuke is coming. The words from the conference comment echoed in Ana’s mind. This wasn't just about homophobia. It was a war against modernity itself. The LGBTQ+ inclusive posters, the gender-neutral uniforms… they were just the newest, most visible symbols of a world that was leaving StoneHeart’s "old ways" behind. The school was a stand-in for the pumphouse. The teachers were stand-ins for the construction crew. She wasn't just a bigot; she was a Luddite of the soul, trying to smash the gears of social progress with her bare, stony hands.

The thread was no longer frayed; it was a hawser cable, pulling her towards something tangible. Ana returned to the folklore website, the one dedicated to British geology. She scoured StoneHeart1968’s profile again, looking for any detail she had missed. Tucked away in the account settings, almost as an afterthought, was an associated email address: L.Hess@provomail.com. A disposable email provider, but the initials were a breakthrough. L.H. Lorna? Laura? Letitia? She ran the initials against public records, cross-referencing them with the 1968 birth year. The search churned for a moment before spitting out a single, thin file. Hess, Lorna. Born 1968. No current address. Last known residence was a council flat in Southwark, an address she'd been evicted from in 2013 for non-payment of rent. The flat was less than a mile from the site of the old Blackfriars Pumphouse.

Lorna Hess. It had the right weight. It felt solid, earthy. A name you could carve on a rock. Lorhainne was its grotesque, frilly costume. Ana felt a cold certainty settle in her gut. This was her. The digital ghost now had a name. She ran it through the national police database. The result was almost more chilling than a long rap sheet would have been. There was only one entry: the minor disturbance at the 2012 pumphouse protest. No other arrests. No driving license. No national insurance activity since the early 2000s. No credit cards. No digital footprint under that name whatsoever. Lorna Hess had, for all intents and purposes, fallen off the face of the earth nearly a decade ago. A ghost in the system.

A human explanation, Davies had said. Ana looked at the screen, at the official void where Lorna Hess’s life should be. A person doesn't just cease to exist in the digital age without a trace. Not unless they stop participating in society entirely. Or unless they were never fully part of it to begin with. The descriptions flooded back. A face of granite and moss. The smell of wet earth and old cellars. The inhuman strength. Ana thought of the old stories her grandmother used to tell, stories of the *drekavac*, the soul of a dead, unbaptized child. Creatures caught between worlds, who raged at the living. Lorna Hess felt like something similar. A being out of time, clinging to a world of stone and soil, raging at the fluid, incomprehensible present.

Ana stood up and grabbed her coat. The hum of the server banks and the stale office air felt suffocating. The hunt had moved beyond the screen. Data had taken her as far as it could. Now, she needed ground truth. She needed dirt under her fingernails. She scribbled a hasty note for Davies—"Pursuing lead on Hess, Southwark"—and clipped it to his office door. She didn't wait for a reply. She was going to the last place Lorna Hess had been a person. The place she had been evicted from. An old council flat near a demolished pumphouse. It was a cold trail, almost a decade old, but it was all she had. And as she walked out into the cool London night, the city lights glinting on the wet pavement, Ana Karrington couldn't shake the feeling that she wasn't just hunting a person. She was hunting a piece of the city's ancient, angry geology that had somehow learned to hate.

The Southwark council estate was a brick-and-concrete testament to post-war optimism slowly succumbing to entropy. Ana navigated her unmarked sedan through the narrow roads, the sleek lines of the car looking alien against the backdrop of peeling paint and rain-streaked balconies. The air here was different from the sterilised atmosphere of central London; it was thicker, layered with the smells of a hundred different dinners, damp washing, and the faint, underlying bitterness of the Thames at low tide. New, impossibly glossy apartment towers loomed in the near distance like polished tombstones, casting long shadows over the older buildings. It was a neighbourhood caught in a geological crush between two eras.

Lorna Hess’s former home was on the fourth floor of a block named Keats House, a cruel irony for a place so devoid of poetry. The communal stairwell smelled of boiled cabbage and disinfectant. Ana’s heels clicked on the worn linoleum, the sound echoing in the concrete well. She found flat 4B, its door painted a cheerful but flaking canary yellow, a desperate attempt at brightness. A young family lived there now; she could hear the tinny theme tune of a children’s cartoon and a baby crying fitfully. Knocking felt like a violation.

Instead, she tried the door opposite. It was opened a crack by a woman whose face was a roadmap of eighty-odd years of London life. A cloud of white hair framed suspicious, watery-blue eyes. A cigarette dangled from her lips, its ash impossibly long.
“Police,” Ana said, holding up her warrant card. “I have a few questions about a former resident of 4B. A woman named Lorna Hess.”

The woman, whose nameplate read ‘E. Vance,’ squinted at the name. She took a long, rattling drag from her cigarette. “Hess? The stone woman? Christ, that’s dredging the river. Haven’t thought about her in years.” She opened the door wider. “Might as well come in. It’s freezing out there.”

The flat was a museum of a life lived. Every surface was covered in knick-knacks, photographs in tarnished silver frames, and stacks of paperback novels. The air was thick with the scent of stale smoke and lavender polish. “She was here when I first moved in, and gone a few years later,” Elsie Vance said, sinking into a floral armchair. “Never said much. Big woman. Moved… heavily. Like it was an effort to lift her feet. Always wore the same big, grey coat, no matter the weather. We called her the stone woman ‘cause she looked like she was carved out of it. And the smell.”

Ana leaned forward, her senses sharp. “The smell?”

“Damp,” Elsie said, tapping her ash into a seashell ashtray. “Not damp from a leaky pipe. A deep-down damp. Like a cellar that’s been locked for a century. Or like the riverbank when the tide goes out. She’d walk past in the hall and the smell would just hang in the air behind her.” Elsie paused, a strange, distant look in her eyes. “My mum, she grew up in the countryside. She had stories about things like that. Things that lived in the bogs and the old quarries. They looked like people, mostly, but they weren't right. They were made of the earth they came from. Grudges made of granite.” She gave a dry, raspy chuckle. “Silly old nonsense, eh? But that’s what Lorna Hess made you think of. Old nonsense.”

Ana felt a chill that had nothing to do with the draught from the window. Grudges made of granite. It was a perfect description. “Did she have visitors? Friends?”

“Never. Not once that I saw. The only time there was a fuss was when they came to kick her out. Bailiffs. Two big blokes. She wouldn’t open the door, so they had to break it down. I watched through the peephole.” Elsie leaned forward conspiratorially. “They went in, and a minute later they came out again, white as sheets. One of them was holding his arm. Said the woman just… picked him up. Picked him right up and put him outside. Didn’t hurt him, just… moved him. Like he was a piece of furniture. They had to call for backup. By the time the police got here, she was gone. Slipped out the back somehow. Left everything behind.”

“Everything?” Ana asked, her pulse quickening.

“Everything,” Elsie confirmed. “Not that there was much. A cot, a chair, some old books. The council had to clear it out. I don’t think the new family that moved in ever knew. They scrubbed the place from top to bottom, but for a year after, you’d still get that smell in the hallway sometimes. The damp.”

Ana left Elsie Vance’s flat feeling as though she had just consulted an oracle. She walked the short distance to where the pumphouse had been. It was now a building called 'Priory Point,' a name that cherry-picked a millennium of history to sell riverside views. It was a fortress of glass and anodized steel, with manicured bamboo gardens and a concierge visible behind a wall of reinforced glass. It was hermetically sealed against the city it occupied. At the edge of the property, set into a small, artfully arranged rockery, was a collection of weathered, carved stones. A plaque identified them as "salvaged architectural fragments from the Grade II listed Blackfriars Pumphouse."

It was a corporate gravestone. A desecration disguised as a tribute. Ana ran her fingers over the cold, rough surface of a carved floral motif, its edges softened by a century of coal smoke and rain. She could almost feel the vibration of a deep, resonant anger. This was the epicentre of the earthquake, the place where Lorna Hess’s tectonic rage had broken the surface. She was a spirit of a place that no longer existed, a ghost haunting the foundations of a luxury that had erased her world.

Her phone vibrated in her pocket. A system alert. A new post had just appeared on "The Righteous Rebuke." Her stomach tightened. She opened the browser, the crude gargoyle background filling the screen. The headline was "An Administrative Error."

*Some lessons are for the pencil-pushers. Mr. Gerald Finney, Vice-Principal of the Chiswick Academy, learned today that budgets and board meetings don't make you safe. He championed the "Rainbow Reads" initiative, putting poison in the school library. I found him in the car park. He tried to lock himself in his fancy German car. The door wasn’t strong enough. He has a very high-pitched laugh for such a portly man. He kept shouting about his "heart condition." A weak heart is no excuse for a weak moral character. The syllabus is expanding. The Headmistress is next.*

The post was more aggressive, the threat more explicit. And the detail about the car door… it wasn't bent, it was torn from its hinges. The local police report, which was automatically appended to Ana’s file, was flagged with a note of incredulity. The responding officers were recommending it be investigated as a vehicular crime, unable to process the witness statement from the terrified, hyperventilating Vice-Principal.

Ana stood in the shadow of Priory Point, the cold of the salvaged stone seeping into her fingertips, the glowing screen of her phone a window into a raw and ancient fury. Lorna wasn't just reacting anymore. She was planning. She was following a curriculum of her own design. The syllabus is expanding. The Headmistress is next. It was a declaration. This wasn’t a crime of opportunity; it was a scheduled appointment. Ana’s mind raced, pulling together the threads. The hatred of modernity, the obsession with teaching lessons, the connection to stone and earth and forgotten places. Lorna Hess wasn't living in a flat. She hadn't been for a decade. A creature like that wouldn't seek shelter among the people she despised. She would go somewhere that felt like home. Somewhere old, and dark, and made of stone. Somewhere forgotten, beneath the city's gleaming skin.

**Chapter 2**

Beneath the city’s skin. The thought was no longer an abstract hypothesis; it was a certainty, as cold and solid as the salvaged pumphouse stone under her hand. Lorna Hess was not a ghost in the system; she was a troll under the bridge, a creature that had retreated into the foundational darkness of the city she saw as a disease. The new blog post, with its chillingly specific threat against the Chiswick Academy Headmistress, was not just an escalation. It was a timetable. Lorna wasn't hiding anymore. She was working from a home base.

Ana’s mind, trained to see patterns and connections, overlaid maps in her head. A map of the Victorian sewer system, a masterpiece of engineering designed by Joseph Bazalgette, a network of brick cathedrals built to carry away the city's filth. A map of the lost rivers of London—the Fleet, the Tyburn, the Walbrook—entombed in pipes and conduits but still flowing, still whispering, beneath the streets. And over it all, a personal map of Lorna Hess’s rage, with its epicentre at the demolished pumphouse. These systems intersected, a tangled circulatory system of forgotten spaces. Lorna was in there. Somewhere.

Back in her car, the engine a low thrum in the quiet street, Ana called Superintendent Davies. She didn't expect him to be pleased.
"Karrington. I have your note. And I've seen the alert from Chiswick. The Met are handling it. They've put a watch on the Headmistress's home."
"Sir, a patrol car isn't going to stop her," Ana said, her voice tight with urgency. "The last victim's car door was torn from its hinges. This is not a person who is deterred by a locked door or a uniformed officer. She’s an anomaly of significant physical power, and she is now predictable."
There was a long, weary sigh from the other end of the line. "And what is your 'unorthodox' proposal, Sergeant? That we send a tactical team into the sewers based on a folklore theory and the testimony of an elderly woman?"

"My theory is that she's using the subterranean infrastructure as a base of operations. The pumphouse at Blackfriars was her trigger. It was connected to the main drainage intercept. She's living in the warren of tunnels beneath Southwark and the City. I need access, and I need a guide. Someone who knows the system."
"This is preposterous," Davies said, his voice clipped. "You want to go on a spelunking expedition looking for a tickle-monster while a real threat exists against a civilian?"
"They are one and the same, sir," Ana said, fighting to keep her tone level. "Putting a guard on the Headmistress is treating the symptom. I intend to find the disease. If you want a human explanation, let me find the human. Give me twelve hours."

The silence on the line stretched, thick with disapproval and reluctant calculation. Davies hated the strange cases, but he hated public failure more. A Headmistress being assaulted on his watch after a direct, public threat would be a catastrophe. "One guide," he finally conceded, the words tasting like ash. "An official from the Thames Water authority. By the book, Karrington. And you will be in constant communication. If you find nothing within six hours, you are to pull out and we proceed with a surface-level investigation only. Is that understood?"
"Understood, sir," Ana said, though she knew a Thames Water official in a high-visibility jacket was the last thing she needed. She needed someone who knew the unofficial city, the one that wasn't on any modern map. As soon as she disconnected from Davies, she pulled up a different number in her contacts, one labelled simply 'Finn - Subterranea'. He wasn't a water authority official. He was a former military combat engineer who, after a tour in Afghanistan, had found the only peace he could in the vast, silent darkness beneath London, charting its forgotten ways. He owed Ana a favour after she’d made his unregistered discovery of a Roman mosaic in an abandoned Tube station ‘disappear’ from official reports, saving it from being paved over.

She met him two hours later, as dawn threatened to break, near a rusted iron manhole cover in a forgotten Southwark alleyway. Finn was a wiry man with a face that seemed to be all sharp angles and a constant, low-level energy, as if he were perpetually listening for something no one else could hear. He was dressed in worn overalls and carried two heavy-duty rucksacks. He handed one to Ana. It contained a powerful headlamp, waders, gloves, and a sealed pack of emergency rations.
"Heard you were hunting trolls," he said, his voice a low rasp. He didn't smile. "Bad idea. They own the ground down there."
"She's just a woman, Finn," Ana replied, pulling on the waders.
"Yeah, and the Thames is just water," he countered, prying the heavy manhole cover open with a grunt. A wave of cool, foul air billowed out, a complex smell of decay, damp earth, and something metallic, like old blood. "Doesn't mean it won't kill you if you don't respect it. After you, Sergeant."

The descent was like stepping back in time. The ladder was cold and slick with algae, and as she climbed down, the sounds of the waking city—the distant sirens, the rumble of the first trains—faded away, replaced by a profound, echoing silence broken only by the steady drip, drip, drip of water. At the bottom, a brick-lined tunnel, just high enough to stand in, stretched away into absolute darkness. Finn landed beside her, replacing the cover with a sound that seemed impossibly loud, plunging them into a world lit only by the beams of their headlamps. The air was heavy, tasting of stone and rot.
"This is an old interceptor," Finn explained, his voice hushed, reverent. "Pre-Bazalgette. Parts of it are Roman foundation. It connects to the old Fleet sewer. The pumphouse would have fed runoff into this network. If your stone woman wanted a place to disappear, this is where she'd come. Miles of it. An empire of shit."

They moved slowly, their beams cutting cones of light through the oppressive black. The floor was uneven, coated in a slick, dark film. The silence was unnerving. Ana was used to the noise of investigation—the chatter of radios, the ringing of phones, the hum of computers. Down here, the only sounds were their own splashing footsteps and the gurgle of unseen water flowing through deeper channels. It was a place outside of time, a place of forgetting. It felt like Lorna's territory.
For two hours, they saw nothing but endless brickwork and the scuttling shapes of rats caught in their lights. The air grew staler, thicker. Then Finn stopped, holding up a gloved hand. He pointed his beam at the wall. There, scratched into the grime-covered brick, was a word. A single, deeply gouged word: POISON.

Ana ran her fingers over the grooves. They were fresh. The brick dust hadn't even been washed away by the constant damp. Someone had carved this with a piece of rock, or maybe just their fingernail. Her blood ran cold. She shone her light further down the tunnel, and there was another one. LESSONS.
"She's marking her territory," Ana whispered, the sound swallowed by the darkness.
"Or leaving breadcrumbs," Finn muttered, his eyes scanning the shadows ahead. "This way."

He led her to a junction where three tunnels converged. In the centre, a maelstrom of dark water churned and flowed into a deeper, wider channel. But to the left, set high above the water line, was a small, arched opening, barely four feet high. It looked like an old overflow outlet, long since abandoned. From within, there was no sound of water, only a dead, still silence. And a smell. The smell Elsie Vance had described. Wet earth, old cellars, and something else—the sharp, acidic tang of an ancient, festering resentment.
Finn checked a device on his wrist. "No hazardous gas. But it's a dead end. Nowhere to go in there."
"That's why she'd choose it," Ana said, her heart pounding against her ribs. She ducked under the archway, her light preceding her.

It wasn't a tunnel. It was a chamber, roughly circular, its ceiling a magnificent dome of Victorian brickwork. A forgotten junction room or a pressure regulator. It was dry, dusty, and filled with a strange collection of objects. In the centre was a crude bed made of piled burlap sacks and old coats. Against one wall was a cairn of stones, carefully stacked, and on top of it sat broken pieces of carved masonry—a stone flower, a fragment of a gargoyle’s wing, a piece of a nameplate with the letters '...HOUSE' still legible. It was a shrine to the demolished pumphouse.
The walls of the chamber were covered in more scratchings, a frenzied manifesto of hate. Scrawled lists of schools. The names of the teachers she had attacked. And in the centre, in huge, jagged letters that dominated the space, were two words: RIGHTEOUS REBUKE. This was more than a lair. It was a temple. A temple dedicated to a religion of one, built on a foundation of pure, undiluted hate. Ana swept her light across the room, taking it all in, the scale of the obsession, the sheer pathological fury of it. This was everything she needed. The proof. The human explanation Davies had demanded.
Then she heard it. From the tunnel behind them. A sound that wasn't water, or rats, or their own movements. It was a scraping, dragging sound. The noise of something heavy and unyielding being pulled over rough brick. It was followed by a low rumble, a sound like shifting rock that resolved, chillingly, into a kind of tune. A tuneless, grating hum.
Finn grabbed her arm, his eyes wide in the reflection of her headlamp. "Company," he breathed. "She's coming back."

**Chapter 3**

Finn’s hand clamped on her arm, his fingers like steel wires. “Kill the light,” he hissed, the whisper sharp and immediate. Ana’s training took over, her thumb finding the switch on her headlamp without conscious thought. The chamber, their grotesque museum of hate, vanished. They were plunged into a blackness so absolute it felt physical, a suffocating velvet that pressed in on her eyes and filled her mouth. The only reality was the cold brick at her back, the frantic pounding of her own heart, and the sound.

The scrape-drag was closer now, just outside in the main tunnel. It was accompanied by the low, resonant hum, a tuneless vibration that seemed to come from the very stones around them. It was a sound of immense mass in slow, deliberate motion. Ana grabbed Finn’s arm, pulling him silently, inch by inch, behind the crude cairn of salvaged masonry. They flattened themselves against the cold brick wall, the sharp edges of the stacked stones digging into their backs. It was pathetic cover, but it was all they had. The air was frigid, yet sweat trickled down Ana’s spine. Every nerve ending was screaming.

A vast shape blotted out the faint greyness of the tunnel entrance, a darkness within the dark. The humming stopped. The silence that followed was worse, thick with listening, with a terrible and ancient stillness. Ana held her breath, convinced the frantic drumming in her ears was as loud as a police siren. She could smell it now, the smell that had clung to Arthur Albright, the smell Elsie Vance remembered. Damp earth, river mud, and the bitter, acidic tang of resentment, so powerful it was almost a taste.

A voice, low and grinding, echoed in the junction just outside their hiding place. “Filth…” The word was a piece of gravel spat from a concrete mixer. “They come down into the clean dark… with their poisons… their bright, shiny poisons…” It wasn't a conversation. It was a catechism, a litany spoken to the darkness itself. “A lesson for the head… a final lesson…”

The shape moved. It stooped, a slow, creaking motion, and a head and massive shoulders filled the low archway into the chamber. Ana couldn't see a face, only a silhouette, a block of night denser than the surrounding black. The creature—the woman—was on her hands and knees, preparing to crawl inside. She paused there, sniffing the air like a great bear at the mouth of a cave. The sound was wet and guttural.

“New smells,” the voice rumbled, vibrating through the floor. “Soap. Sweat. The stink of the surface. The stink of… law.”

Ana’s hand went instinctively to the cold grip of the Sig Sauer holstered at her hip. A single shot. In this confined space, the sound would be deafening, the ricochet unpredictable. It was a last resort, a suicidal one. Her mind raced, sifting through options, finding none. They were trapped. Cornered.

Then she felt a touch on her arm. Finn. He wasn’t looking at the entrance. His head was turned towards the wall beside them. He had been running his free hand over the brickwork, a silent, desperate exploration. He tugged her sleeve twice, a sharp, insistent command. Then he guided her hand to the wall. The bricks were slick and uniform, but under her trembling fingers, she felt it: a vertical line where the mortar was different. It was coarser, sandier. It wasn't Victorian brickwork. It was a patch. An old one.

He leaned in, his lips brushing her ear, his breath a hot burst in the cold air. “Ventilation shaft. To the Embankment. Bricked up in the fifties. Thinner than the main wall.”

A chance. A sliver of impossible hope. But it was on the other side of a wall of brick. They had no tools, nothing but their own bodies. As if reading her mind, Finn pressed something hard and angular into her palm. She recognised its shape instantly. It was one of the smaller, sharper pieces of salvaged stone from the cairn. A weapon. A tool.

Lorna Hess began to move again, her huge form starting to squeeze through the archway. The sound of her heavy coat scraping against the brick was agonisingly loud. In moments she would be inside, her impossible strength trapping them in a space no bigger than a prison cell. There was no time for subtlety. It was now or never.

Ana met Finn’s unseen gaze in the dark, a silent agreement passing between them. He pointed at a spot on the wall, and she understood. He would use his body as a ram, focusing all his weight on the weakest point. Her job was to use the rock, to strike at the mortar, to create the first crack for him to exploit.

He took a deep, shuddering breath. Lorna was halfway through the opening, a grunting, monstrous shape of pure menace. Ana raised the heavy stone, her muscles screaming with the effort of holding it steady. This was it. The human explanation was about to meet them, and their only answer was to bring the ceiling down on themselves. Finn launched himself at the wall. The impact was a dull, sickening thud, and at the same instant, Ana brought the rock down with all her strength against the sandy mortar line.

The sound was a cannon shot in the stillness, a crack of fracturing brick that was instantly answered by a roar from the entrance—a sound of geological fury, of a tomb disturbed. The hunt was over. The fight had begun.

The roar that answered them was not a sound of lungs and vocal cords. It was a tectonic event, a shearing of rock deep within the earth. The entire chamber seemed to shrink, the air compressing under the weight of sheer, malevolent pressure. The silhouette in the archway stopped being cautious and became a battering ram of flesh and fury. With a grating shriek of fabric against brick, Lorna Hess surged into the chamber, her massive form moving with a speed that defied her bulk. She was a landslide in a crypt, and Ana and Finn were the flimsy structures in its path.

There was no time for thought, only for the frenzied repetition of their single, desperate act. "Again!" Ana screamed, her voice a raw tear in the fabric of the dark. Finn, his face a pale blur, threw himself at the wall once more. The thud was heavier this time, wetter, the sound of a body finding its limits. Ana brought her stone down on the same spot, and this time she was rewarded with a spiderweb of cracks radiating from the point of impact, a fine mist of ancient mortar puffing into the air like a dying breath. A faint tracery of lines, visible for a split second before being swallowed by the gloom. It was enough. It had to be.

Lorna was no longer crawling. She was on her feet, her head bent low beneath the domed ceiling, a hunched giant in the claustrophobic space. She couldn’t see them clearly, but she didn’t need to. She lunged towards the sounds of their destruction, a huge arm sweeping through the dark. Ana felt a gust of foul, cold air as a hand passed inches from her face. Then came a choked cry from Finn. The sweeping hand had found its mark. In the blackness, Ana heard a sickening, wet crunching sound. Lorna’s fingers, the fingers Arthur Albright had described as being like sausages, had closed around Finn’s leg. It was the sound of a vice grip, of pressure being applied beyond the limits of bone and sinew.

A wave of pure, adrenalized terror washed over Ana, so cold it was almost calming. She knew in that instant that a bullet would be useless, a firecracker against a mountain. She could not fight Lorna. But she could fight the wall. She screamed, a wordless sound of defiance, and swung the rock one last time. She put her fear, her anger, the full weight of her body into the blow. This time, there wasn't just a crack. The wall imploded. A section of brickwork, two feet square, collapsed inwards in a chaotic waterfall of stone and dust, revealing a passage of even more profound blackness beyond. A new wind, smelling of dust and distance, gusted into the chamber, a promise of somewhere else.

The sudden noise and collapse caused Lorna to momentarily shift her attention. In that same instant, Finn’s flailing body knocked Ana’s headlamp. It flickered on, its beam cutting a frantic, bouncing swathe across the scene. For a horrifying second, the chamber was illuminated. Ana saw Finn, his face contorted in agony, his leg bent at an unnatural angle in Lorna’s stony grasp. And she saw Lorna’s face. It was everything the victims had described and worse. A craggy, asymmetrical landscape of granite-grey skin, flecked with what looked like actual moss in the deep crevices. Her eyes were not human; they were chips of jet, burning with a cold, ancient light. Her mouth was a wide gash, pulled back in a snarl of tombstone teeth. Without thinking, Ana dropped her rock, scooped up a jagged piece of the pumphouse shrine—the fragment with the word 'HOUSE' on it—and hurled it at the monstrous face.

The heavy stone fragment struck Lorna square on the cheek with a sharp crack, like a plate breaking. The impact would have felled any normal person. Lorna barely flinched, but she did grunt, a surprised, guttural sound, and her head snapped to the side. Her grip on Finn’s leg loosened for a single, crucial second. It was all Ana needed. She grabbed Finn by the collar of his overalls and hauled him backwards with a strength she didn’t know she possessed. "Go! Now!" she shrieked, shoving him towards the jagged opening. He half-crawled, half-fell through, his injured leg dragging uselessly behind him, his cry of pain swallowed by the crumbling passage.

Ana dove in after him, scrambling through the tight, rough-edged hole. Jagged bricks tore at her clothes and her skin, but she barely felt it. Behind her, she heard Lorna’s renewed roar of outrage, followed by a thunderous crash as the creature smashed the cairn to pieces in a fit of pique. Then came a new sound, the terrifying splintering and groaning of brick as Lorna began to tear at the hole they had made, widening it with her bare hands. They collapsed together in a heap on the other side, in a narrow, coffin-like ventilation shaft thick with the dust of ages. They were through. They were alive. But in the suffocating darkness, listening to the monster tearing down the wall to get to them, Ana knew their desperate flight had only just begun.

**Chapter 4**

There was no time for assessment, no space for fear. There was only the roar from the other side of the ruptured wall and the choking dust that filled their lungs. The darkness in the ventilation shaft was ancient and absolute, a solid thing that clung to them like wet clay. Ana’s headlamp, miraculously still functional, cut a single, trembling path through the black. It illuminated Finn’s face, a mask of chalky white, his teeth gritted against a pain that was beyond sound. The beam slid down to his leg, and Ana’s stomach lurched. The heavy fabric of his overalls was twisted and bunched, and the limb beneath lay at an angle that defied anatomy. Behind them, the scraping and splintering of brickwork grew louder, more frantic. Lorna was coming through.

"Up," Ana grunted, the word a puff of dust. "On me. Now." She hooked her arms under his, hauling him with a surge of adrenaline that set her own torn muscles screaming in protest. Finn cried out, a muffled, guttural sound, but he tried to help, pushing with his good leg. They were a clumsy, three-legged beast, stumbling into the unknown. The shaft was barely wide enough for one person, forcing them into a grotesque, shuffling embrace as they moved. Finn’s injured leg dragged behind them, its passage marked by a wet, scraping sound on the gritty floor that was nearly as terrible as the sounds of their pursuer.

The noise from behind was changing. The frenzied tearing had stopped, replaced by a rhythmic, heavy thud. It was the sound of footsteps. A slow, inexorable, two-beat rhythm. *Thump-scrape… thump-scrape…* It was the gait of something that knew it didn't need to run. It was the sound of a glacier advancing, of a cliff-face eroding, of an inevitable end drawing closer with every step. The beam of Ana’s headlamp bounced and jittered, revealing nothing but an endless, receding tunnel of brick, slick with a century of slime. The air grew colder, and a new smell joined the dust and decay: the deep, mineral chill of the nearby river.

"Junction… ahead," Finn gasped, his voice thin and reedy. His weight was becoming a deadening anchor, his consciousness flickering. "Feel the draft?" Ana hadn't, but now that he said it, she could. A faint, almost imperceptible current of colder air against her cheek. It was a sign of life, of a connection to the world above. The thumping behind them grew louder, closer. Lorna was faster in the straight, narrow confines than they were. The acoustics of the tunnel played tricks, sometimes making her sound as if she were right on top of them, sometimes as if she were miles away, but the steady, grinding rhythm was a terrifying constant.

They staggered around a shallow bend and the shaft opened slightly, intersecting with another, narrower conduit. A rusted iron ladder was bolted into the brickwork, ascending into a square of total blackness. It was a way up, but it was also a dead end if it led nowhere. "Is it clear?" Ana asked, her own breath coming in ragged sobs. Finn, leaning heavily against her, craned his neck, his eyes squinting into the dark. "Service duct. Runs parallel to the Embankment wall. Should lead to a storm drain outlet. It's a chance." The thumping was deafening now, echoing from the bend they had just rounded. They had seconds, nothing more.

"You first," Ana ordered, pushing him towards the ladder. "Use your arms. Go." He looked at her, his eyes wide with a mixture of pain and protest, but there was no time to argue. He grabbed the cold, slick rungs and began to haul himself upwards, his useless leg dangling. Ana unholstered her Sig Sauer, the familiar weight a small, cold comfort in the primal dark. She turned, planting her feet, pointing her light and her weapon back down the tunnel. The beam landed on Lorna as she rounded the bend. The sight was a physical blow. She was even larger than she'd seemed in the chamber, her immense frame filling the shaft from wall to wall. Her grey coat was torn, her granite face smeared with brick dust, and the stone fragment Ana had thrown had left a dark, weeping gash on her cheek. Her eyes, those cold chips of jet, fixed on Ana, burning with a hatred that was older than the city itself.

She didn't speak. She didn't roar. She lowered her head and charged. It wasn't a run; it was an avalanche, a horrifying surge of mass and power that was meant to crush, to obliterate. Ana had a split second. The shot would be deafening, the ricochet a wild card, but there was no choice. Above her, Finn had made it only a few rungs up the ladder. He was a perfect target. She pulled the trigger. The explosion of the gunshot in the confined space was apocalyptic. It was a physical concussion, a flash of white-hot light that bleached all colour from the world, and a sound that shattered the air, the brick, her eardrums. It was the sound of the modern world screaming back at the ancient one.

The world disappeared into a roar of white. The muzzle flash, magnified a thousand times by the confining tunnel, burned a searing afterimage onto Ana’s retinas. It was followed by the physical punch of the concussion, a brutal fist of air that slammed into her chest and threw her back against the base of the ladder. The shriek of the gunshot was instantly replaced by a high, piercing whine in her ears, a solid wall of sound that blotted out everything else. For a timeless second, she was deaf and blind, adrift in a universe of ringing silence and swimming purple blotches, the acrid, chemical smell of burnt cordite a shocking violation of the tunnel’s ancient, earthy breath.

As her vision began to swim back into focus, the beam of her headlamp, knocked askew, strobed and flickered across the scene like a faulty projector. In those disjointed flashes of light, she saw Lorna. The creature was on one knee, not felled, but forced down by the sheer kinetic energy of the impact. The 9mm round had struck her just below the neck, on her broad collarbone. There was no blood. There was no wound as Ana understood it. Instead, in the stony, grey flesh, there was a small, star-shaped crater, a pockmark from which a dark, viscous fluid, thick as tar, was beginning to sluggishly ooze. Lorna’s head was raised, and the sound that emanated from her was not one of pain, but of profound, geological outrage. It was the grating of continents, the groan of a fault line. The bullet had not hurt her. It had insulted her.

That single kneeling moment was a gift. “Finn!” The name was a shredded croak, lost in the ringing of her own ears. Ana jammed her pistol back into its holster and threw herself at the ladder. The iron rungs were vibrating, humming with the shockwave of the gunshot and the deeper, resonant fury of their pursuer. She scrambled past Finn, who was frozen on the rungs, his face slack with shock. “Move!” she yelled, getting a rung above him, her hands grabbing the collar of his overalls to haul him upwards. Below, the monstrous pause ended. With a shriek that was pure, grinding stone, Lorna launched herself at the ladder, her huge, thick-fingered hands closing around the lowest rung. The entire metal structure shuddered and groaned, protesting the impossible weight.

It became a vertical race against a nightmare. Ana climbed, pulling and pushing Finn, her muscles burning, her lungs on fire. Finn, spurred by the horror below, moved on pure instinct, his arms working like pistons, his good leg finding purchase. The sounds from below were terrifyingly close: the creak and groan of stressed metal, the scrabbling of Lorna's heavy boots on the rungs, and a low, continuous growl of hate that vibrated up the ladder and into their bones. They reached the top and spilled out onto a narrow iron catwalk, collapsing in a heap. The space was different here. Larger. Colder. They were in a vast, cylindrical brick conduit, at least thirty feet in diameter. A river of black, fast-moving water rushed through the bottom, its roar a constant, deep-throated thunder. The air was a torrent, a wind that promised an exit.

Ana pushed herself up, her light cutting through the cavernous dark. Across the roaring channel, maybe forty feet away, was their salvation: a huge storm drain outlet opening onto the Thames, a circle of slightly less intense blackness, barred by a massive iron grate. But their immediate problem was climbing the ladder behind them. Lorna’s head appeared over the edge of the catwalk, her face a mask of terrible resolve. The weeping crater on her collarbone seemed to pulse in the flickering light. She placed one stony hand on the catwalk, then another, and began to haul her immense body up. The metal walkway swayed and groaned under the new weight, its old bolts shrieking in protest. The chase wasn't over; it had just moved to a far more treacherous stage.

The catwalk swayed like a rope bridge in a gale. The ancient iron, never designed for such a weight, screamed in protest as Lorna Hess planted both feet on its narrow surface. Each of her steps was a hammer blow, sending violent shudders through the metal and down into the bones of Ana and Finn. She rose to her full, stooped height, a creature of primordial malice silhouetted against the faint light of Ana's flickering lamp. Her craggy face was set in a mask of grim finality, the weeping crater on her collarbone a dark, obscene third eye.

"Nowhere left to run, little officer," the voice rumbled, a sound that was somehow louder than the roaring torrent of water below. "The lesson ends here." She took another step, and a bolt somewhere beneath them sheared off with a sharp crack, dropping their section of the catwalk a terrifying inch. Finn cried out, scrabbling backwards, his good leg pushing him away from the advancing horror. Ana shoved him behind her, planting her feet as wide as the narrow walkway would allow, creating a flimsy human shield between her wounded guide and the approaching monster. Her mind was a maelstrom of failed options. She was out of tricks, out of tunnels, out of time.

Lorna raised a hand, her thick fingers flexing, ready to grab, to crush, to deliver her final, tactile rebuke. The gun. It was a pathetic, modern toy against this elemental force, but it was all she had left. Ana raised the Sig Sauer, her hands slick with a mixture of sweat and grimy water. She steadied the barrel, her sights trained not on the creature's chest, but lower, on the crumbling brick and rusted iron at Lorna's feet. The catwalk was their prison, but it was also a machine. A rusty, decaying machine that could be broken.

Lorna saw the shift in Ana’s aim and a sneer cracked her granite face, a fissure of contempt. "More toys," she rasped. "You cannot break what is stone." She lunged.

Ana fired. The shot was an ear-splitting concussion, a flash of fire and fury in the subterranean gloom. The bullet didn't strike Lorna. It screamed past her leg and slammed into the point where the main support strut for that section of catwalk was bolted to the brickwork. The slug, designed to expand in soft tissue, did something spectacular to the rust-eaten iron and crumbling mortar. It acted like a demolition charge. The bolt head disintegrated into shrapnel, and the strut, suddenly freed from its anchor, tore away from the wall with a shriek of tortured metal.

The world tilted. The section of catwalk beneath Lorna’s feet dropped away, plunging downwards at a sickening angle. For the first time, a look of genuine shock crossed the creature’s face. She, a being of earth and stone, of solid certainties, had been betrayed by the very ground she stood on. Her immense weight worked against her, pulling her down with the collapsing walkway. She windmilled her arms, her impossible strength for once useless against the simple, ancient law of gravity. She roared, a sound of pure disbelief, as she fought to find purchase on the buckling, twisting metal.

Ana didn't hesitate. Her ears were ringing, her vision blurry, but her mind was icily clear. She aimed at the next support, further back, closer to her own position, and fired again. The second shot was the killing blow for the dying structure. The catwalk gave way entirely, a twenty-foot section tearing free from the wall in a single, catastrophic failure. With a final, agonized groan of shearing metal, it swung downwards like a hangman’s trapdoor and plunged into the churning black river below.

Lorna Hess went with it. Her roar was cut short as she was swallowed by the torrent, her massive form vanishing beneath the black, frothing water with a tremendous splash that sent a wave crashing against the opposite wall. The current was a liquid engine, powerful and relentless. It seized her, pulled her under, and began to drag her away into the deep, roaring darkness of the main conduit, towards the river and the sea.

The violence of the collapse threw Ana and Finn against the wall, their hands gripping the ladder and the small, shuddering fragment of catwalk that remained. The noise subsided, replaced by the constant thunder of the water and the high, thin whine in Ana’s ears. They clung there, trembling, their breaths ragged clouds in the cold air, and stared at the churning water where the monster had been. There was nothing. No hand, no head, no sign of a struggle. Lorna was gone, swallowed by the city’s dark, forgotten bloodstream.

Ana’s strength gave out. She sagged against the ladder, the heavy pistol slipping from her numb fingers, clattering once on the remaining metal before falling silently into the water below. It was over. The hunt, the chase, the fight. It was over. She looked at Finn, whose face was a ghostly white in the bouncing beam of her headlamp. He was staring at the water, his eyes wide with a terror that was slowly being replaced by disbelief.

"Is she…?" he whispered, unable to finish the sentence.

"She's gone," Ana said, the words feeling hollow, insufficient. She wasn't dead. Ana knew, with a certainty that settled like ice in her gut, that a thing like Lorna Hess didn't die so easily. She had been defeated, washed away, returned to the cold, dark, flowing elements she so resembled. They had survived. Slowly, painfully, Ana began to move, pulling Finn with her. Their only path was across the remaining fragment of walkway to the storm drain outlet. Step by agonizing step, they shuffled towards it, towards the grey light that was now clearly visible through the massive iron grate. It was the light of dawn over the Thames. A new day. They had made it back to the surface, but Ana knew, as she felt the cold London air on her face, that something ancient and full of hate was now loose in the river, waiting. The syllabus was not finished. It had only been postponed.

**Chapter 5**

The grey light of the London dawn, filtered through the thick, rust-eaten bars of the storm drain grate, was the most beautiful thing Ana had ever seen. It was a pale, watery light, promising a world of traffic noise, overpriced coffee, and indifferent crowds, and she craved it like a drowning woman craves air. The thunder of the sewer conduit behind her was a physical force, a constant reminder of the roaring blackness that had almost claimed them. In front of her was the river, its tidal slap and suck a comparatively gentle rhythm. They were caught in the city’s throat, perched on a precipice between two worlds. Ana’s whole body was a symphony of pain; her muscles trembled with a violent, uncontrollable post-adrenaline crash, and the ringing in her ears had subsided into a dull, persistent hum. Beside her, Finn had slumped into a state of semi-conscious exhaustion, his breathing shallow, his face the colour of old parchment.

Her service phone, miraculously, was still functional inside its waterproof case. Her fingers were clumsy and stiff, her screen smeared with filth, but she managed to dial. She didn’t call Davies. She called the Met’s emergency line, her voice a raw, cracked version of its usual self. "This is Sergeant Ana Karrington, Interpol SAD. I am on the Victoria Embankment, approximately two hundred metres east of Blackfriars Bridge. I am… below you. Inside storm drain outlet seven. I have an injured civilian, requires immediate medical extraction. Bring hydraulic cutters. And a lot of blankets." She didn't elaborate. There were no words for the truth that would make sense over a crackling phone line to a dispatcher. Let the mundane world deal with the aftermath; it was what it was good at.

The wait was an eternity suspended between the roar of the sewer and the approaching scream of sirens. To the commuters beginning to trickle across the bridge above, it was just another Tuesday morning, another distant emergency. To Ana, huddled on the last remaining fragment of the catwalk, it was the final, agonising crawl to shore. The flashing blue and red lights first appeared not as a direct beam, but as a frantic, pulsing reflection on the surface of the dark water below. Then came the sounds: the slamming of vehicle doors, shouted commands, the heavy, purposeful tread of boots on the pavement directly over their heads. Faces appeared at the grate, silhouetted against the morning sky—firefighters, their helmets catching the light. Their expressions were a mixture of professional focus and sheer bewilderment, trying to process the sight of two people, looking like they had clawed their way out of a grave, huddled on a broken piece of iron in a sewer outlet. The whine of the hydraulic spreader, the Jaws of Life, was the sound of salvation, its powerful teeth biting into the corroded iron bars that had been their final prison.

Emerging onto the solid pavement of the Embankment was a violent rebirth. The air was bitingly cold and tasted of diesel fumes and damp pavement, a stark contrast to the subterranean fug. Paramedics immediately swarmed Finn, their calm, efficient movements a bubble of order in the chaos. Ana found herself wrapped in a thick, coarse wool blanket, a steaming cup of sweet tea pressed into her hands by a police constable whose face was a mask of polite, unasked questions. She watched as they loaded Finn into the ambulance, his leg now immobilised, his eyes briefly finding hers with a look of dazed gratitude before he was whisked away. The world felt slow, muffled, unreal. A senior police officer approached her, notebook in hand, but stopped short, taking in her appearance—the torn clothes, the grime, the haunted look in her eyes. He cleared his throat. "Sergeant Karrington? We've… secured the area. What exactly were you pursuing down there?" Ana looked from the officer’s clean, pressed uniform to the dark, gaping maw of the drainpipe, and a bubble of hysterical laughter threatened to rise in her throat. "Maintenance issues," she said, her voice flat. "It's a long story."

The story was one Superintendent Davies did not want to hear. He listened from behind the fortress of his desk later that afternoon, his face a study in controlled fury. Ana, cleaned and in a spare uniform from her locker, recounted the events in a clipped, dispassionate monotone, stripping the tale of its mythic terror and rendering it as a sequence of operational facts: discovery of the subject’s lair, hostile engagement, structural failure of the access way, subject lost in the main sewer outflow. She omitted the moss-flecked skin, the geological roar, the way the bullet had cratered rather than pierced. She knew it would do no good. Davies’s disapproval was a cold, dense mass in the room. "You discharged your firearm in a confined public space," he said, his voice dangerously quiet. "You led a civilian into an unsecured zone, resulting in grievous injury. You caused, by your own admission, the destruction of a piece of Victorian infrastructure. And your suspect, Lorna Hess, is… where, exactly? At the bottom of the Thames?"

"Yes, sir. Presumed drowned," Ana stated, meeting his gaze without flinching. "I stopped the attacks. The threat against the Chiswick Headmistress has been neutralised." Davies steepled his fingers, his eyes cold. He was a man cornered by a success he could neither acknowledge nor celebrate. "The official report will state that Lorna Hess, a disturbed individual and the prime suspect in the Northgate assaults, was tracked to the sewer system. In the course of her apprehension, she fell into a storm channel and was swept away. Her file will remain open but inactive. The 'Giggling Menace' case is, for all public purposes, closed." He leaned forward, his voice dropping. "You, Sergeant, are on mandatory administrative leave, effective immediately. Pending a full psychological review. Go home, Karrington. And stay there."

She disobeyed him, of course. Her first stop was the hospital. Finn was in a private room, his leg encased in a formidable cage of metal pins and rods. The pain medication had taken the edge off his agony, leaving his eyes lucid but distant. He looked at the stark white walls, the beeping machines, and gave a weak, wry smile. "Bit cleaner than my usual digs," he rasped. Ana stood by the bed, a profound sense of guilt churning in her stomach. "Finn, I'm sorry." He shook his head, a slight, pained movement. "Don't be. I knew the risks. We went into the dark places. Sometimes the dark pushes back." He looked at her then, his gaze intense. "That thing… it wasn't just a woman. You felt it, didn't you? It was old. A grudge made of granite, like your old lady said. And the river… the river doesn’t kill things like that, Ana. It just moves them. Gives them a new place to settle."

Later, in the sterile silence of her own apartment, Finn’s words echoed in her head. The flat, usually a sanctuary of clean lines and quiet order, felt flimsy, a temporary shelter against a world that had suddenly revealed its monstrous, hidden depths. Sleep was impossible. She found herself at her computer, pulling up a hydrographic chart of the Thames. She saw it not as a line on a map but as a living entity, a vast, dark artery connecting the entire city, its currents reaching into forgotten creeks, lapping at ancient foundations, depositing silt and secrets along its banks. On a morbid, self-punishing impulse, she typed the URL for "The Righteous Rebuke." She expected the site to be gone, a ghost left behind in the tunnels. But it loaded instantly, the crude, grinning gargoyles seeming to sneer directly at her. And there was a new post. It had been uploaded less than an hour ago. The title was a single word: *Recess.* The post itself was even shorter, a single line of text that made the blood freeze in her veins. *The water is cold. But it remembers the old paths. Class will resume.*
